results.title: Australian women's heritage: 1945-1986
results.brief_description: This program starts with the post-war baby boom and goes on to look at immigration, housing, views on women’s work, the rock and roll craze and the new morality, the pill, censorship and equal pay - all issues highly relevant to Australian women in this era. Issues important to Aboriginal women are also explored. Some individual women highlighted in this episode are Germaine Greer, Bobbie Sykes, Kath Walker, Dawn Fraser, Dame Joan Sutherland, Jan Marsh, Judith Wright and Pat O’Shane.

results.title: Australian women's heritage: 1901-1945
results.brief_description: This visual history of Australian women documents the contribution of an often overlooked group. Their work, their mothering and their civilising influence has been a major factor in Australia’s coming of age. Yet women have been receiving second class status from officialdom since the earliest days of Australia’s settlement. This program begins by looking at the reduction in the size of families, the White Australia policy and changes in society’s views on morality. It looks at both World Wars and their impact on Australian women. The contrast between the flappers and the poverty of the 1920’s is interesting to consider. Jewish refugees and British immigrants, votes for women, changes in fashion and issues important to Aboriginal women are all discussed. Individual women highlighted in this episode include Vida Goldstein, Muriel Heagney, Elizabeth Kenny, Dame Enid Lyons, Dame Mary Gilmore and Katherine Suzannah Pritchard.

results.title: Australia's anti-war movement: 1965-1972
results.brief_description: The initially small minority protesting against Australian involvement in the Vietnam War flourished into a massive mobilisation against the war that not only ended Australian participation in the war, but also radicalised and irreversibly changed Australian society. In this video three participants in the anti-war movement discuss their involvement. Irene Miller was an original member of the Save Our Sons Movement, one of the earliest of the anti-war organisations. Michael Hamel-Green was a draft resister and he gives a fascinating account of the “underground” movement which worked to protect draft resisters from prison by installing them in “safe houses”. Jean McLean discusses the history of the anti-war movement and the lead up to the first anti-war Moratorium in 1970, the largest protest in Australia’s history.

results.title: Organics: food for thought
results.creator_credit: Jim Testa, Mike Laker and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs
results.brief_description: Organic farmers work with nature rather than against it, a process of positive cooperation with the soil, without the intervention of chemicals, in order to produce a quality product. Filmed on location in Victoria, this video covers the production, marketing, export potential and labelling of organic produce in Australia. It features citrus grower, Robert Ridgewell; bio-dynamic wheat/sheep farmer, John Greenwood; vegetable grower, Neville Cann and Ian Diamond, organic wholesaler.

results.title: Ceremonial ground painting: Aboriginal women artists from Papunya
results.creator_credit: Ian Stocks, Robyn Bondfield, Kopano P/L Productions and Queensland Art Gallery
results.brief_description: Eight women artists from the Papunya community were invited to Queensland Art Gallery to create a groundpainting that would enhance and extend the exhibition “The Inspired dream: life as art in Aboriginal Australia” This video documents the making of the painting, explanations of its symbolic meaning and the dancing ceremonies which are traditionally performed when the work is finished. The artists were Emma and Mali Nungurrayi, Topsy, Mary and Jeannie Napaltjarri, Mavis Napangati, Phylis Nakamarra and Mavis Nampitjinpa.

results.title: Images of the land: 100 years of Australian landscapes
results.creator_credit: Ian Stocks and Queensland Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Highlights the work of some of Australia’s most important artists from the 19th century to the present time. Includes the works of Arthur Streeton, Hans Heysen, Russell Drysdale, Sidney Nolan, Fred Williams and others who present us with their visions of the Australian landscape.

results.title: Hard work and hope: Australia's Italians
results.creator_credit: Equality Press and Italian Historical Society
results.brief_description: Designed to enable Australian Studies students appreciate the role of migrant labour in Australia. Focuses on the theme of work as experienced by Italian immigrants both before and after World War II. Photographs, newsreel footage and moving footage from the Italian Historical Society documents the contribution of Australia’s Italians to the community through their work. Accompanied by a 19p. Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: Make It Right
results.creator_credit: Central and Northern Land Councils and Inst of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: An impressionistic account of the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke’s, 1988 visit to the Barunga Festival in remote Northern Territory. Thousands of Aboriginal people travel to this, the largest Aboriginal sports and cultural festival in Australia. In this particular year Mr. Hawke received a petition from the Aboriginal people for recognition of their rights, and in turn he pledged the drawing up of a treaty between black and white Australia. This treaty has yet to be made.

results.title: Aboriginal Education in Victoria: VAECG
results.creator_credit: Vincent O'Donnell, Melbourne State College. Media Production Centre and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Explains the workings of the Victorian Aboriginal Education Consultative Group. Shows how the group operates with Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in Shepparton, Robinvale and Echuca. Introduced by Norman Lacy, Assistant Minister of Education.

results.title: Broken white line
results.brief_description: A documentation of the role of an Aboriginal social worker, depicting the enormity of the problems he is called upon to help solve in the Aboriginal community. DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE MATERIAL, TEACHER PREVIEW OF THE FILM BEFORE CLASSROOM SCREENING IS ESSENTIAL.
